extendedIngredients.name: tilapia
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 tilapia fillets, about 300 g. total weight

recipes.title: Tilapia and baby portobello mushrooms in cream sauce

winePairing.pairingText: Fish on the menu? Try pairing with Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. The Tiamo Pinot Grigio with a 4.2 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 8 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Tiamo Pinot Grigio
productMatches.description: Light straw yellow color. Fresh and rich fruity aromas of apple and pear with a hint of citrus fruit that fade into the floral bouquet. Fresh and fruity, very clean and crisp.Tiamo Pinot Grigio pairs well with a wide array of lighter cuisine, especially fish/shellfish, poultry, pastas in cream sauce and softer cheeses. It's also an ideal aperitif.

recipes.instructions: InstructionsPat the tilapia fillets dry with a kitchen towel. Cut into two-inch cubes. Toss lightly with salt and pepper.Slice the mushrooms.Peel and roughly chop the onion.Heat the butter in a pan. Add the chopped onion and cook gently over medium heat until translucent, about 10 minutes.Turn up the heat to high. Add the fish to the pan and cook, stirring gently, for about a minute.Add the mushrooms. Pour in the fish stock. Bring to the boil. Simmer for a minute.Pour in the cream. Stir gently. Season with salt and pepper. As soon as the sauce boils, turn off the heat. The residual heat will cook the fish and mushrooms through.Transfer the cooked dish to a shallow bowl, garnish with parsley and serve at once.

steps.step: Pat the tilapia fillets dry with a kitchen towel.
Cut into two-inch cubes. Toss lightly with salt and pepper.Slice the mushrooms.Peel and roughly chop the onion.
Heat the butter in a pan.
Add the chopped onion and cook gently over medium heat until translucent, about 10 minutes.Turn up the heat to high.
Add the fish to the pan and cook, stirring gently, for about a minute.
Pour in the fish stock. Bring to the boil. Simmer for a minute.
Pour in the cream. Stir gently. Season with salt and pepper. As soon as the sauce boils, turn off the heat. The residual heat will cook the fish and mushrooms through.
Transfer the cooked dish to a shallow bowl, garnish with parsley and serve at once.
